body:
https://docs.perl6.org/language/testing#Writing_tests:

> A typical test file looks something like this:
> 
> ``` perl6
> use v6;
> use Test;      # a Standard module included with Rakudo
> use lib 'lib';
> 
> plan $num-tests;
> 
> # .... tests
> 
> done-testing;  # optional with 'plan'
> ```

Should it also have `#!/usr/bin/env perl6` (or something else) on the first line?

I have some stats for you! I have cloned every repo in the ecosystem. Then, with a bit of magic, I got this:

```
  702 total                          ← couldn't clone 7 modules (709 modules in ecosystem)

  476 no shebang
   78 #!perl6
   68 #!/usr/bin/env perl6
   61 no tests                       ← :(
   11 can't decide                   ← different shebang lines in test files
    3 #!/usr/bin/perl6
    1 #!/usr/local/bin/perl6
    1 #! /usr/bin/env perl6
    1 #! /Users/damian/bin/rakudo*   ← oops
    1 #!perl6                        ← with trailing whitespace
    1 #! perl6
```

You can see lists of modules for every shebang here: https://gist.github.com/AlexDaniel/b5e15174c624f95ae50334ddd23f546f

Note that these stats do not show modules that have a shebang line in some files but not in others (they are shown as having one shebang). Also, there may be some false matches.

Um, so what's the conclusion?
title: “A typical test file looks something like this” – what about shebang line?
